title: Which is stronger: Adamantium, Vibranium or something else? - Quora

response.answer_text: Adamantium is a harder, more resistant material. Think of it as Iron when everything else is Aluminum. It resists warping so much that the only way to work it is to engage it while it’s in a molten or near molten state! The amount of stress and strength it would take to bend or snap a piece of… say, adamantium rebar is almost ridiculous and even Thor or the Hulk would have trouble managing it. It’s that resistant to distortion and bending. Unfortunately, it’s that same inflexibility which makes it destructible (not easily, mind you). That which cannot bend will break when under enough stress — it just requires a ludicrously high amount of stress to break adamantium (kind of why it’s called that). Vibranium is literally on a different scale. Completely different. As in, cannot actually be compared. It’s like asking if Usain Bolt is a superior athlete to Michael Jordan. Adamantium is strong because it takes a lot to bend it. That’s literally all there is to it. Vibranium is a lot more complex. Vibranium is strong because it bends so incredibly easily, but invariably returns to its original shape when the pressure is gone. If Adamantium is like Super-Iron, and thus will eventually give way when finally overstressed, Vibranium is like an unsnappable rubber band — it’ll just give and give and give as long as you pour energy into it, until the energy it’s stored overpowers the energy you’re putting into it, which results in a MASSIVE explosion of raw kinetic energy that would reduce Isaac Newton to highly impressed yet terrified tears. This is why Captain America’s shield REFLECTS bullets rather than simply stopping them dead in their tracks like a conventional shield: it’s actually gathering and redirecting the bullet’s kinetic energy according to the shape of the shield’s surface rather that absorbing and dispersing that energy. And it’s why Black Panther’s suit in the movie can make an EARTH SHATTERING KABOOM if hit with enough force (“DELETE THAT FOOTAGE!”). Captain America’s shield is actually made of both. Most of the base construction is Vibranium, which gives it its startling kinetic properties, and it’s fortified with an early, experimental Adamantium alloy that grants it just enough rigidity that it can’t be bent back enough to expose or harm Cap. So in the end, Vibranium is probably “stronger”, just because the amount of abuse you’d have to give it to permanently compromise its structure after being cast would be so great that the resultant explosion would realistically atomize the vibranium along with whatever was vaguely nearby. Adamantium would give long before that point. If you survive such an explosion, or it just plain doesn’t occur when the Vibranium snaps… congratulations. You’re the favorite character of whoever is writing your comic book and they’ve sacrificed the rules for Rule of Drama.

Adamantium is definitely the strongest metal of the two but it doesn’t mean that it’s necessarily the best to use in all circumstance. As you’re probably aware one of the key things that vibranium does is absorbs almost any impact or vibration that is directed against it so, defensively, it can be considered the better to use than adamantium. But, as I say, it’s only almost all impacts and the defensive properties of vibranium can be overcome if it’s sufficient force or sharpness used against it. For example, the Black Panther’s suit is made using a vibranium weave in the comics just like it is in the films and during fights between Black Panther and Wolverine, Wolverine’s adamantium claws have been shown to be able to slice through it and draw blood;  During the Black Panther film as well there was a scene where Shuri had specifically mentioned to T’Challa that he shouldn’t consider his suit completely indestructible and warned him that too much impact(s) against it could eventually overload it and that was the main reason why his upgraded suit had the capability of redirecting the energy of the impacts and expelling it as concussive blasts. But if the question is being asked in order to find out what the strongest metal full stop in the Marvel universe is then the overall strongest is no doubt adamantine. That’s what Hercules’ Mace is made from and Amadeus Cho explains it’s properties to Wolverine pretty well here;  There’s since been a retcon that when adamantium was originally created it was done because the inventor was actually trying to find and recreate the process that makes adamantine so if you take that and put it into Layman’s Terms then adamantine is stronger than adamantium due to being “Godlier” than it. Also, it’s worth noting that there’s even a superior form of vibranium than normal vibranium (usually referred to as Wakandan Vibranium) and that’s Antarctic Vibranium or, as it’s more commonly known as, Anti-Metal. That shares the same properties as Wakandan vibranium but it can also cause a chemical reaction when it interacts with other metals and causes the other metal to melt, basically. Hence the “Anti-Metal” name it has. Misty Knight’s prosthetic arm is made of it;   So, as that shows, Antarctic vibranium is definitely a superior version of Wakandan vibranium and can even “melt” adamantium. In the comics, Black Panther’s claws in his suit are made from the Antarctic variation of vibranium to be more effective against armoured opponents. It seems that, in the MCU, the claws on his suit are just standard Wakandan vibranium, though. But, for the original question, adamantium is the stronger of the two and I was only adding the other two examples in case the question was asking for what is considered the strongest (or most effective) type of Marvel metal to use? Hope that helps, anyway.
